Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: RUI: Collaborative Research: Exploiting Information Graphics in a Digital Library

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a collaborative effort between the University of Delaware and Millersville University. Information graphics (non-pictorial graphics such as bar charts and line graphs) occur frequently in popular media such as newspapers and magazines. Not only is the knowledge conveyed by these graphics very often not included in the article's text, but (in contrast with scientific documents) the article's text most often does not even explicitly refer to the graphics. Information retrieval research has focused on the text of documents, and their information graphics have largely been ignored. Yet, the graphic designer considered the graphic's message important enough to warrant designing a graphic to convey it. This project's goal is a novel methodology for retrieving relevant information graphics from a digital library in response to user queries.

Information graphics in popular media generally have a communicative goal or message that they are intended to convey. This message encapsulates the high-level knowledge contained in the graphic. The approach of the project is a language model that treats the relevance of a graphic to a query as a mixture of three components: a graphic's intended message, other textual components of the graphic such as its caption and additional textual description augmenting the caption, and the text of the document containing the graphic. Challenges that are being addressed include identifying the portion of the article that is relevant to the graphic, associating query terms with the intended messages of graphics in the document library, expanding the abbreviated captions and additional textual descriptions of graphics to more fully capture their content, and appropriately weighting the contribution of individual components of the mixture model. In addition, some kinds of graphics, such as grouped bar charts, have both a primary intended message and a secondary message. The impact of the secondary message on retrieval when an ideal graphic is unavailable is also being addressed. Evaluation of the graph retrieval methodology consists of experiments in which human subjects rate the relevance of retrieved graphics to user queries.

The goal of this project is to produce a system for retrieving relevant information graphics, thereby expanding the utility of digital libraries. Together with the SIGHT system, which conveys the content of information graphics via speech, the project will extend the information resources available to individuals with sight-impairments. The project will also produce a corpus of information graphics and their XML representations that can be used by other researchers. Corpora and research results will be disseminated on the project web site (http://www.cis.udel.edu/~carberry/Graph-Retrieval). In addition to significantly increasing the resources accessible from a digital library, the research will lay the foundation for expanding research on question-answering to take into account information graphics. The project will contribute to the development of future scientists by educating graduate students, providing research opportunities for undergraduates at a predominantly undergraduate institution, and enhancing the mentoring skills of graduate students as they work on a team that includes undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The amount of information available electronically has increased dramatically over the past two decades. Research efforts in information retrieval, information extraction, and question answering have helped make this information accessible by providing tools for identifying documents of interest and for analyzing documents to extract knowledge from them. However, these research efforts have focused primarily on the text of the documents and, to some extent, on the pictorial images in the documents. Unfortunately, the information graphics (non-pictorial graphics such as bar charts and line graphs that depict attributes of entitiesand relations among entities) have been largely ignored.

The Intellectual Merit of the overall collaborative project was the development of a novel methodology for retrieving information graphics. This included research into the impact of a graphic's intended message on estimating the relevance of the graphic to a user query and how the intended message should be taken into account in an algorithm for retrieving information graphics. 

This project was a collaborative one between researchers at the University of Delaware and researchers at Millersville University. The remainder of this report pertains to the work done at Millersville University, with the outcomes of the work done at University of Delaware appearing in their separate report.

One of the major outcomes of the work completed by researchers at Millersville University was the development of a publicly available corpus of information graphics. This corpus now contains nearly 2,000 bar charts and line graphs. The majority of entries also contain information about the context of where the graph appeared (source, article text, etc.) Many of the graphics are annotated as to the intended message of the graph (rising trend, comparison of entities, etc.) This should be an invaluable resource for future researchers. 

Another significant outcome achieved by the Millersville University researchers involved the extension of previous research findings. A University of Delaware researcher had developed a methodology for identifying the most relevant paragraph in an article for a given line graph that appeared with the article. An undergraduate researcher from Millersville University extended this work to identify the most relevant paragraph for a bar chart. This was not a straightforward task, due to key differences between line graphs and bar charts. The student completed a Departmental Honors Thesis on this project. Her work was published at a regional conference where she received the Best Paper Award.

In terms of Broader Impacts, five undergraduate students worked extensively on the project over the years. These undergraduates were all positively impacted by this research experience. Three of these students came from underrepresented groups within computer science and within the STEM disciplines as a whole. The majority of the students were also first-generation college students. One of the students is planning to pursue a PhD in Computer Science.  Providing quality undergraduate research experiences continues to be a focus of the Millersville University Computer Science department.
